    • Profile: Pocket Guard: Turn Off Display In Pocket ID:89 (condition State: Proximity Sensor   (code:125) and State: Display State   (code:123)) [DISABLED] flags: 10
      • TaskerNet description: Turn off the display if your phone is in your pocket and accidentally turns on. It'll also turn off the display if you put it in your pocket while it's turned on. It'll wait 5 seconds until it turns it off to prevent false positives. This is achieved by checking the proximity sensor on your device, so please make sure that your device has a working proximity sensor if you want to use this.

  • Project: Weather [Launcher Task: Show Weather]
    • TaskerNet description: Multiple weather related profiles and tasks:

    Check the current weather

    Check today rain probability

    Check Sunset and Sunrise times

    Profile to automate something based on if it's going to rain

    Profile to automate things based on sunset and sunrise times with optional time offsets

  • Project: Task Logger
    • TaskerNet description:

    Write Tasker Tasks and Events to Google Sheets. No setup needed, it works instantly. (Working demos are included.) Just copy-paste a single Task Action into a Task and see variable data logged to an online spreadsheet, including accurate timestamps. Very useful for keeping an ongoing record of any sorts of events or for debugging Tasks.

    With one extra click you can even tell it to auto-create graphs or pie-charts from your data ‘on the fly’. You can simply drop it in or take it out of any Task and it can collect any selected data instantly without affecting the Task, the data then uploads in the background to write into a spreadsheet. Collecting different data from different Tasks and writing to different spreadsheets is easy to do   (Reddit Link)

    .

     

          

     

        TaskerNet search on: Google Sheets,Web,Data

        •   continued >>> Infinite Loop, (condition: If %counter < 8)  code: 135-


  • Project: PrfTsk List
    • TaskerNet description:

    Profiles and Tasks Lister/LoggerList and optionally log all of your Profiles and Tasks.

    All functionality is self-contained in this project.

    Logging is done upon request by incorporating the functionality of TaskLogger and are logged to a shared public "Google Sheets" spreadsheet. If you wish to deploy your own spreadsheet, refer to TaskLogger here.

    This is an extension of this this Profile List, and has all of the functionality of this other project built-in, including copy-to-clipboard of selected profiles/tasks and invocation of selected profiles/tasks.

    After installing this project, add the task "PT List Profiles and Tasks" to your phone's desktop as a tasker shortcut and run it from there. You will be prompted for:

    - Once the profiles are listed, do you want to log them?

    - If you responded "yes" to logging, then you will be prompted for the sheet/tab name in the public spreadsheet to log to. Try to use a unique name to avoid stepping on top of someone else's log.

    - Once the tasks are listed, do you want to log them (via TaskLogger)?

    - If you responded "yes" to logging, then you will be prompted for the sheet/tab name in the public spreadsheet to log to. It can be the same name as used for your Profiles, or another name just for your Tasks.

    - If either is logged, do you want to wait for the logging to complete?

    This last prompt is provided since the logging could potentially take a minute or more. If you wait, it will show you the remaining log count every 5 seconds until the log is completed. If you don't wait, the task will end and the logging will complete in the background.

    Here's what you will see in this specific order:

    - A scrollable scene displaying all of your Profiles

    - Once you click on "Quit" or "X", you will get a prompt asking if want to log the results. If you respond "yes", you will be prompted for the spreadsheet sheet/tab name to use and the Profile-names logging will occur in the background.

    - A scrollable scene displaying all of your Tasks

    - Once you click on "Quit" or "X", you will get a prompt asking if want to log the results. If you respond "yes", you will be prompted for the spreadsheet sheet/tab name to use and the Task-names logging will occur in the background. you will be asked if you want to wait for the logging to complete. If you say "yes", then every 5 seconds you will be flashed a count of the remaining log entries to be processed. If you say "no", the task will exit and the completion of the logging will occur in the background.

    A second task is included, PT View Spreadsheet, which can be used to display the Google Sheet in a browser or via Google Sheets (if this app is installed on your phone).

    Note: Logging of say, up to 52 profiles and 140 tasks can take upwards of seven minutes or more. Check your output before rerunning this to make sure the previous run has completed.

    Note: You can view the spreadsheet here.

    Credit goes to Godberd for use of the TaskLogger code.   TaskerNet search on: Google Sheets,Utility,Display

  • Project: Apps [Launcher Task: Set Last App Navigation Bar]
    • TaskerNet description: Switch to last app with either a bubble or navigation bar icon. Demo here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WdawhsMpmLk Also included are some other demos that you can do with the new App actions in Tasker, like showing a pie chart of the most used apps, or a notification or navigation bar with the 5 most recent apps that you can switch to.

    • Profile: Keep Track Of App Usage ID:309 (condition Event: App Changed   Priority:0 (code:2078)) [DISABLED] flags: 2
      • TaskerNet description: Important: need the Tasker beta for this. (https://joaoapps.com/beta-testing/) Will show a notification of the time you spent in an app in the last 24 hours. Will show a pop-up notification if you've used the app for over 60 minutes in a single day.

  • Project: Location On Checker
    • TaskerNet description: Use this project to make sure your Location stays on unless you absolutely want it off. This project will notify you when your Location is off, give you the option to turn Location on, and will automatically turn on at a desired time (default is midnight).   • Project: Don't Break It
    • TaskerNet description: Time Flip 1.1 For Battle Cats Automated -2/+2 Time Flip Mess it up and loose energy for a week. There is a failsafe, notated twice, it can still go wrong though. currently working on building a database of all the days of the month and eventually I won't have to go set the date each day. your best bet is to erase all the days but one and do it yourself each day. it will account for the beginning two days of the month and go back a calenders month. If you came here from a link and don't know what Tasker and/or the 2 2 is, turn around a and research them first. Otherwise you will probably click the wrong thing and get your account booted for a week. It should work, after you reconfigure the x, y coords for every input. Just redo each action and use the easy click function. You will need AutoInput, AutoTools, maybe another Plugin, and of course Tasker. You can replace the everything, even the programmatic autodate switcher if you want with an autoclickers, and your feeling lucky.   TaskerNet search on: AutoInput,AutoTools,Time

  • Project: Google Drive Viewer
    • TaskerNet description:

    Google Drive Viewer allows files to be viewed (without downloading) in Google Chrome for Android.

    Setup

      The following apps are required: Tasker, AutoShare, and AutoTools

      Set up the AutoShare command

        Open AutoShare

        Main Menu - Manage Commands - plus sign

          New Command = View File

          Browsing for files = Direct URL

          URL = https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Google_Drive_icon_%282020%29.svg/1280px-Google_Drive_icon_%282020%29.svg.png

          Priority = 1

        Main Menu - Share Targets - ensure “AutoShare Command” is checked

      Import the project into Tasker using the button below (this page must be viewed on your Android device for the button to appear)

    Usage

      Long-tap a file link in Chrome

      Tap “Share link” - “AutoShare Command” - “View File”

      If a file can’t be natively previewed in Google Drive, you may be able to connect an app that can preview the file

    Settings

      By default, the file will open in a new tab. To adjust this setting, open the “Google Drive Viewer” task in Tasker and set %newtab (line 1) as follows:

        true: file will open in a new tab

        false: file will open in the same tab currently being used

      TaskerNet search on: AutoShare,AutoTools,Files

    • Profile: View File ID:176 (condition Event: AutoShare   , Priority:0 (code:580953799)) [DISABLED] flags: 2

  • Project: Fake Call
    • TaskerNet description: Fake call project. Uses Autonotification and AutoTools (but you might be able to adjust the actions involving them to use regular Tasker). Works by either setting a profile timer using a scene or by initiating the Fake call task on its own. You'll need to change two things in the Fake Call scene: the big picture of the phone (change to one of your contact's pictures) and the name of the caller. Tap on them in the scene to change. Two other changes are needed for authenticity: in the Initiate Fake Call task, change the Play Music to one of your own ringtones and in the Call Notification task, change the text to your contact. The Call Notification task uses a Google wave net voice; change that if you don't have access to them. You might also need to change the size of the Fake Call scene base rectangle so it covers the whole area of your phone screen. Tap on a blank bit of the scene to access it, and make it bigger.   TaskerNet search on: AutoNotification,AutoTools,Scenes

    • Profile: Fake Call Time ID:220 (condition Time: from %FakeCallTime to %FakeCallTime and State: Variable Value   (code:165)) [DISABLED] flags: 10
      • Task: Initiate Fake Call    <<< Entry Task  Task ID: 216    [Priority: 100]
        • 01: AutoInput Unlock Screen   Unlocking Screen.
        •   continued >>>
        •   continued >>> Android 7 and above:
        •   continued >>> This will only unlock your screen if you're using a non-secure lock screen or if Smart Lock (Trusted Places, Trusted Devices, etc) is currently active.
        •   continued >>>
        •   continued >>>
        •   continued >>> Android 6 and below:
        •   continued >>> it's highly recommended that you use the Tasker 'System Lock' action at the end of this task. If you don't, your screen's lock will be permanently off and your system might even become unstable.
        •   continued >>>
        •   continued >>> This action WILL NOT work with a secure screen lock even if you are using Smart Lock. It will only work if you have screen lock security set to none or swipe. Timeout:10   code: 234244923-
        • 02: Wait   MS:0 , Seconds:1 , Minutes:0 , Hours:0 , Days:0  code: 30-
        • 03: Do Not Disturb   Mode:Allow All,   code: 312-

  • Project: Voice Command Capture
    • TaskerNet description:

    Voice Command Capture version 1.0.1.

    Allows to capture voice commands from Google Assistant and other sources.

    Importing the localization strings is also required:

    taskershare://AS35m8nuYECCRZX6Z3dLemrH8t2K4h9Dkn9B%2Fr8F9Ydfsp0xZ%2BgRGC87lUwDzJgqI09t65c%3D/Project%3AVoice%20Command%20Capture%20-%20Localization

    Please read the project documentation at https://github.com/malversoft/tasker.vcc before proceeding.   TaskerNet search on: Assistant,AutoInput,AutoVoice

  • Project: Message Handler
    • TaskerNet description: TLDR; Plays incoming messages and let‚Äôs you reply by voice for any messaging services which shows a Reply action in its notification.

    I have tested with Android Messages, Google Voice, and Microsoft Teams. This is a work in progress, and based on the ToDo‚Äôs listed at the end, I think I will need to make some fairly dramatic changes, breaking it into multiple tasks instead of one long task with labeled sections, but it is working well enough now to share version 1.

    Any recommendations for ways to do things better are always appreciated. When I upgraded to Android 12 and lost Android Auto phone mode, the one feature I could not replace was the ability to listen to and respond to text messages by voice.

    (I don‚Äôt want to use Assistant Driving mode for numerous reasons, the primary one being it doesn‚Äôt work properly in Landscape mode, but there are others).

    I tried several apps, and nothing worked well or had all of the features, so I wrote this task. The first 4 lines (labeled Auto-respond to new messages) checks if this is a message from the same person who last messaged me, or a new sender.

    If a new sender, it responds that I am driving and will respond as soon as I am able, and then sets a variable with this sender as the last sender.

    If they send more messages, it will skip the auto-reply.

    This allows me to ignore messages if I am in traffic and don‚Äôt want to deal with them right now.

    (my ‚Äúin car‚Äù profile clears this variable so it starts empty each time I get in the car). label: ‚ÄúTurn off music if playing‚Äù Checks is music is playing, and what music player is in use.

    If music is playing, it saves the player to a variable for use later, and pauses the music. Lable: ‚ÄúSpeak Speaker‚Äù speaks the sender name and asks if I want to listen to the message.

    Any answer but Yes, goes to the end label. Label: ‚ÄúSpeak Message‚Äù reads out the message and then asks if I want to reply, repeat or cancel, and has Goto‚Äôs appropriate for those responses (anything other than reply or repeat assumes cancel and goes to the end label) Label: ‚ÄúAsk What to Reply‚Äù asks me to speak my reply, and then reads it back, asks if I want to send it or re-record it.

    Saying Stop will go to the end lablel Not responding currently defaults to sending the message after the AutoVoice Recognize timeout, but I may want to change that to assume cancel instead. Label: ‚ÄúSend Message‚Äù replys to the message, and says ‚Äúmessage sent‚Äù Label: ‚Äúend‚Äù cancels the message notification (if it leaves it there, new messages cause it to read the first one, instead of the new one.

    I am sure this is fixable in Autonotification but I haven‚Äôt figured it out yet).

    It then restarts the media if it was playing originally and clears the is_media_playing variable so it is reset for the next time. Profile: The profile uses Autonotification to identify notifications with reply actions for the apps I specify.

    Change the selected apps to your own messaging apps.

    It also only triggers when I am connected to my car Bluetooth, so also adjust this one to your own BT devices. Requires: Autonotification. AutoVoice. A google API key for Say Wavenet, although changing the Say Wavenet to Say actions should work fine. Todo: 1) Better handling of multiple messages while task is running.

    Not sure where to start this, but I suspect in the Autonotification trigger in the profile is the first place to look.

    2) I really want a scene with big buttons that pops up and allows me to do all of the functions except for speaking the response, and a few buttons for common replies as well.

    I believe I will need to break each label into a separate task to do that, meaning a complete re-write, so I will probably live with this for a few weeks and verify there are no other bugs before I try to take that on, but if you download and use this, keep an eye out for a version 2 rewrite.

    Again, any suggestions for this would be appreciated.

    I have very little experience creating and using scenes.


    • Profile: Reply When Connected To BT ID:380 (condition Event: AutoNotification Intercept   Event Behaviour: true Notification Type: Only Created Notifications Has Reply true Notification: Apps: Teams,Voice,Messages,Messages,Messenger , Priority:0 (code:1520257414) and State: BT Connected   Name:SB360/Galaxy Buds Pro (825D) (code:3)) [DISABLED] flags: 10

    • TaskerNet description: TLDR; Plays incoming messages and let‚Äôs you reply by voice for any messaging services which shows a Reply action in its notification. I have tested with Android Messages, Google Voice, and Microsoft Teams.

      This is a work in progress, and based on the ToDo‚Äôs listed at the end, I think I will need to make some fairly dramatic changes, breaking it into multiple tasks instead of one long task with labeled sections, but it is working well enough now to share version 1. Any recommendations for ways to do things better are always appreciated.

      When I upgraded to Android 12 and lost Android Auto phone mode, the one feature I could not replace was the ability to listen to and respond to text messages by voice. (I don‚Äôt want to use Assistant Driving mode for numerous reasons, the primary one being it doesn‚Äôt work properly in Landscape mode, but there are others). I tried several apps, and nothing worked well or had all of the features, so I wrote this task.

      The first 4 lines (labeled Auto-respond to new messages) checks if this is a message from the same person who last messaged me, or a new sender. If a new sender, it responds that I am driving and will respond as soon as I am able, and then sets a variable with this sender as the last sender. If they send more messages, it will skip the auto-reply. This allows me to ignore messages if I am in traffic and don‚Äôt want to deal with them right now. (my ‚Äúin car‚Äù profile clears this variable so it starts empty each time I get in the car).

      label: ‚ÄúTurn off music if playing‚Äù Checks is music is playing, and what music player is in use. If music is playing, it saves the player to a variable for use later, and pauses the music.

      Lable: ‚ÄúSpeak Speaker‚Äù speaks the sender name and asks if I want to listen to the message. Any answer but Yes, goes to the end label.

      Label: ‚ÄúSpeak Message‚Äù reads out the message and then asks if I want to reply, repeat or cancel, and has Goto‚Äôs appropriate for those responses (anything other than reply or repeat assumes cancel and goes to the end label)

      Label: ‚ÄúAsk What to Reply‚Äù asks me to speak my reply, and then reads it back, asks if I want to send it or re-record it. Saying Stop will go to the end lablel Not responding currently defaults to sending the message after the AutoVoice Recognize timeout, but I may want to change that to assume cancel instead.

      Label: ‚ÄúSend Message‚Äù replys to the message, and says ‚Äúmessage sent‚Äù

      Label: ‚Äúend‚Äù cancels the message notification (if it leaves it there, new messages cause it to read the first one, instead of the new one. I am sure this is fixable in Autonotification but I haven‚Äôt figured it out yet). It then restarts the media if it was playing originally and clears the is_media_playing variable so it is reset for the next time.

      Profile:

      The profile uses Autonotification to identify notifications with reply actions for the apps I specify. Change the selected apps to your own messaging apps. It also only triggers when I am connected to my car Bluetooth, so also adjust this one to your own BT devices.

      Requires:

      Autonotification.

      AutoVoice.

      A google API key for Say Wavenet, although changing the Say Wavenet to Say actions should work fine.

      Todo:

      1) Better handling of multiple messages while task is running. Not sure where to start this, but I suspect in the Autonotification trigger in the profile is the first place to look.

      2) I really want a scene with big buttons that pops up and allows me to do all of the functions except for speaking the response, and a few buttons for common replies as well. I believe I will need to break each label into a separate task to do that, meaning a complete re-write, so I will probably live with this for a few weeks and verify there are no other bugs before I try to take that on, but if you download and use this, keep an eye out for a version 2 rewrite. Again, any suggestions for this would be appreciated. I have very little experience creating and using scenes.

      •   TaskerNet search on: AutoVoice,Messaging,AutoNotification

  • Project: Snap Camera
    • TaskerNet description: Take automatic 'n' number of photos with your Samsung phone.

    Designed for S21 Ultra, it should work with other current Samsung phones with the latest camera app. You will be prompted for the number of seconds before starting, the number of seconds between shots, and the total number of photos to take. Create a desktop shortcut to this task to easily trigger-start it.

  • Project: Pinned Notes
       [Kid App: Package:com.tasker.tameirao.kyle, Version Name:1.0, Target Android Version:29
        Features: 1=android.hardware.bluetooth:y, 2=android.hardware.camera:y, 3=android.hardware.camera.flash:y, 4=android.hardware.wifi:y

  • Project: Elevenlabs Voice Synthesis [Launcher Task: Elevenlabs Setup]
    • TaskerNet description:

    Use Elevenlabs voices for text to speech generation in Tasker!

    Check out a full demo of this here!

    At the time of writing these voices sound much more natural than the ones that are built-in to Tasker so that's why this project was created.

    You can use this to fully replace your Say or Say WaveNet actions if you want.

    This uses their HTTP API. Documentation available here.

    Usage tips:

      Before importing this project, visit the Elevenlabs website, log in, click on you profile picture on the top right, click on "Profile" and click the little eye icon so you can see your API Key. Copy that key.

      When importing this project make sure to run the setup task when prompted, so that you can insert your API Key and choose the assistant's voice.

      If you want to change the voice you can re-run the Elevenlabs Setup task.

      You can use the Text To Speech Elevenlabs task in any of your text to synthesize speech. Use the Perform Task action to do that and set Parameter 1 as the text you want it to say out loud. Check out the Test Elevenlabs Text To Speech task to see an example.

      You can voice chat with ChatGPT and have responses read by this by using the Voice Chat ChatGPT Elevenlabs task. Make sure to first import the ChatGPT project to make it work.

    Please note that the Elevenlabs API is a paid service, although it has a free tier that you can use with some restricitons. Check out their website above for more info.   TaskerNet search on: Artificial Intelligence,Developer's Choice,Text-To-Speech

  • Project: Proofread

    • Profile: Proofread ID:333 (condition Event: AutoShare Process Text   Text Processor: Proofread , Structure Output (JSON, etc), Priority:0 (code:1133159835)) [DISABLED] flags: 10
      • TaskerNet description:

      Proofread any text you're currently writing in any app!

      This uses the ChatGPT project so please import that before using this.

      Important Note: You need AutoShare for this profile to work.

      Instructions:

        Import this profile

        Open the AutoShare main app

        Click the Text Processors option

        Add a new text processor

        Name it Proofread and set any icon for it

        When prompted, say that you want to modify the selected text.

        When prompted, set the timeout to 30 seconds.

        Open Tasker, expand the Proofread profile, click on the AutoShare condition and edit it.

        Select the Text Processor you created before and hit ok on the top right.

        Back out all of the way from Tasker to save and it should work now!

      In any app, simply select the text you're writing > Menu > AutoShare > Proofread and it should replace your text with a proofread version of it!   TaskerNet search on: Artificial Intelligence,AutoShare,Developer's Choice

      • Task: Unnamed/Anonymous.    <<< Entry Task  Task ID: 332    [Priority: 6]
        • 01: Variable Set   Name:%astext, To:Hello my a friend , Max Rounding Digits:1 (condition: If %astext not set)  code: 547-
        • 02: Variable Set   Name:%prefix, To:System >> , Max Rounding Digits:1  code: 547-
        • 03: Perform Task   Name:%prefix Clear Chat , Priority:%priority , Structure Output (JSON, etc),   code: 130-
        • 04: Perform Task   Name:%prefix Send Chat, Priority:%priority , Parameter 1:Proof read but write only the revised version and nothing else. don't add quotes around your response:
        •   continued >>>
        •   continued >>> %astext, Return Value Variable:%response , Structure Output (JSON, etc),   code: 130-
        • 05: AutoShare Process Text   Processed Text: %response Timeout:60 , Structure Output (JSON, etc)  code: 319692633-

  • Project: Chat GPT
    • TaskerNet description: Use ChatGPT with Tasker!

    Check out the video demo for this project here!

    Very important before you get started: The ChatGPT API is a paid service, but for Tasker uses it seems like a very cheap service. I've used it extensively in the creation of this project making more than 500 requests and I didn't even reach a $0.01 usage. It's still at $0.00. üòÖ.

    To summarize, you do need to add a payment method, but you'll most likely end up paying very, very little, unless you use this a whole lot.

    Also, start by generating an API Key here so you have it handy to paste it into the prompt that shows up when you import this project.

    This project provides the basis of interaction with the ChatGPT API. Tasks that interact with the API or provide other "library" like help are marked with System >> in their names and are not supposed to be used by you directly, unless you want to create new functionality. If you do, check out how the tasks/profiles below are built so you know how to use these "System" tasks correctly.

    The other tasks and profiles in the project will give you a few examples on how you could use ChatGPT in Tasker:

      Set Assistant Personality: aill allow you to set the general behaviour of the responses. For example, you could set it to something like 

      You are a very helpful assistant called "Happy GPT" that always introduces itself before its first response. You call people "Master" and treat them like queens or kings, always asking if they want you to make any offers to them.
      like in the demo video and make it behave that way.

      Task - New Chat: will start a new chat with ChatGPT and then will continuously loop showing you answers and wait for another prompt from you with input dialogs.

      Task - Continue Chat: will continue the last chat you were on, also with input dialogs.

      Task - Voice Chat: will start a new chat where it'll ask you to say something out loud and it'll also respond out loud. It'll loop this interaction until you say "stop". Imporant Note: for this to work you need an API key to use the Say WaveNet action to generate more realistic voices. You can replace the Say WaveNet action in this task with a normal Say action if you want.

      Summarize WhatsApp Notifications: will read your current WhatsApp notifications and summarize their text so that you can quickly and easily know which unread messages you have. Important Note: You need at least version 4.2.10 of AutoNotification for this to work. You may need to sign up for the beta.

      Profile - Simple Chat Bot (don't enable profiles on import if you don't want this): every time you receive a message it'll send back a response from ChatGPT. To start a new conversation you have to receive a WhatsApp message with the text start, otherwise it'll continue on with the current conversation. This is a very rudimentary chat bot that's probably not very useful, but it can give you an idea of where to start building your own for your needs. Important Note: You need AutoNotification for this.

    The project relieas on the following variables:

      Project Variable - %messages: Contains a JSON structure of the current conversation. The ChatGPT API requires you to always send all messages in the current conversation so it has context. If you don't send the full "thread", it won't have any context and won't recall past messages.Important Note: ChatGPT will charge you for how much text it sends back to you but also for how much text you send it, so keep that in mind when sending very large conversations.

      Project Variable - %prompt: A description of the assistant's personality. You can easily change it with the Set Assistant Personality task described above.

      Task Variable in task "System >> Send Chat" - %api_key: Contains your personal API Key. Don't share it with anyone.

    A note for Tasky users: Use the built-in tasks mentioned above by adding them to your home screen with the Tasker Shortcut widget (long-click home screen > add Widget)   TaskerNet search on: Developer's Choice,Text-To-Speech,Artificial Intelligence

  • Project: OpenAI DALL¬∑E [Launcher Task: Test Generate Image With Voice]
    • TaskerNet description: Generate an image based on text using Artificial Intelligence.

    Video Demo here.

    Before using this you need to have an API key. You can generate one here. If you import this from TaskerNet you'll be prompted to insert the key on import. If you import this via XML file you can open Tasker > click on the OpenAI DALLE project at the bottom > Properties and insert the value there in the %api_key variable.

    If you don't already have an account with OpenAI you can create one for free, and when you do so they provide you with $18 USD in free usage credits. Each DALL-E image costs $0.04, and your free credits expire in three months. You may need to become a paid user of OpenAI at that point.

    If you don't have a valid API key, or you free credits have expired you may get error messages using this project. For example, Billing hard limit has been reached.

    To use this in Tasker, use the Perform Task action to call the Generate DALL¬∑E Image task and set Parameter 1 as your prompt. You'll get back the result in the return variable.

    To see a working example of this, edit the Test Generate Image task to see how it's done.

    Important Note: to use in Tasky, open the Routine and select to Reconfigure it.   TaskerNet search on: Developer's Choice,Media


    • Project has no Profiles

  • Project: Display And Lock State
    • TaskerNet description:

    Will create several useful display-related variables that you can use anywhere in your projects:

      %AOD: Will be set to 1 if the Always-On-Display is showing, unset if not. Can be used to show info-only scenes on your AOD with Blocking Overlay + type scenes

      %DisplayOn: Will be set to 1 if the Display is on, unset if not (can be locked or not locked).

      %Locked: Will be set to 1 if the Display is locked, unset if not (display can be on or off). Can be used to destroy scenes that you don't want to show while the phone is unlocked for example.

      %LockScreen: Will be set to 1 if the Lock Screen is showing (while the display is on), unset if not. Can be used to show interactive scenes on your Lock Screen with Blocking Overlay + type scenes

      TaskerNet search on: Developer's Choice,Display,Utility

Projects Without Profiles...
>Project Useful has no Profiles

CAVEATS:
- Most but not all Task actions have been mapped and will display as such. Likewise for Profile conditions and Plug-ins.
- This has only been tested on my own backup.xml file. For problems, report them on https://github.com/mctinker/Map-Tasker.
- Tasks that are identified as "Unnamed/Anonymous" have no name and are considered Anonymous.
- All attempts are made to retain embedded HTML (e.g. color=...>") in Tasker fields, but is stripped out of Action labels and TaskerNet comments.
